oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Inscription on the Past from Present Inquiries: Historiography of Nineteenth Century Chinese Immigrant Public Women
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Huang, Carol
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Chinese immigrant women arrived in America's West in the mid nineteenth century. Their arrival marked the beginning of Chinese American women in the United States of America [1]. They left very few documents of their own. They were assumed to have followed the Chinese men to the West after the gold rush to serve the men. A majoritity of them were called "One Hundred Men's Wives" or prostitutes [2]. In the Western construction and conceptualization of Chinese women of this particular time, they have been portrayed as victims of patriarchy and the capitalist system.
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Education Leadership Research Center, Texas A&M University
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Advancing Women in Leadership Journal; Vol. 19 (2005 Fall)
